Award.AwardTitle: Cellular and Molecular Mechanisms of Spiralian Development
Award.AbstractNarration: A key question in the field of developmental biology is what fundamental mechanisms are responsible for specifying different cell fates during embryogenesis? A related question in the field of evolutionary biology is how have these mechanisms been deployed to generate the tremendous array of animal phyla and their distinctive body plans? Large gaps in our knowledge are due to the fact that only a small number of animal models have been chosen for such studies. This research focuses attention on representatives of a poorly studied group of organisms, the spiralian lophotrochozoans, which encompass nearly one-third of all living animal phyla (including molluscs, annelids, etc.). The proposed studies deploy a powerful combination of modern cell and molecular biology approaches to reveal fundamental information about basic mechanisms that ultimately control the differentiation of embryonic cell fates and axial properties, using an ideal spiralian model system, the snail Crepidula. More specifically, this research will uncover key embryonic cell signaling events and the underlying molecular pathways that ultimately specify the fates of cells during development. Other studies suggest that many of these processes have been conserved across the animal kingdom, including in humans. The findings of this study will be compared with those gained from other animal systems to understand the degree to which these events have changed over the course of evolutionary history. This research has a broader impact not only in terms of the science, but also in education. NSF funding allows the continued training of future generations of scientists and teachers, which include undergraduate and graduate students, who will work on these projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Spiralia (Lophotrochozoa) include 14 animal phyla (e.g., Mollusca, Annelida, Nemertea, etc.) with diverse larval and adult body plans, yet many share a stereotypical pattern of embryonic cell divisions, called "spiral cleavage."  As one of the three largest groups of bilaterally symmetrical animals (“metazoans”), they occupy a key position for understanding the evolution of morphological complexity, not just within the Spiralia, but in the animal kingdom. Unfortunately, unlike the other two clades (the Ecdysozoa and Deuterostomia), few developmental studies have included representatives of the Spiralia. This project specifically examined the fundamental roles that early embryonic cell(s) play as key signaling centers (so called "organizers") in directing the fates of other embryonic cells and in setting up embryonic axes and polarity properties. Using a model spiralian, the gastropod snail Crepidula, we showed that a single cell (the mesentoblast) plays this key role early during development.  We showed further that earlier signaling events actually specify this cell. Hence, the data support a more complicated, multistep model of organizer specification and activity than had been previously understood. We also showed that the cell that serves as the organizer can differ in other species, and that these events can change over the course of evolutionary history. 

Furthermore, we generated a high resolution fate map to follow the specific contributions of the organizer to various parts of the developing embryo. We found that this cell gives rise to many endodermal and mesodermal fates in the larva and the adult, including the hindgut, heart, certain muscles, and the primordial germ cells that will ultimately form sperm and eggs for the next generation. Finally we identified specific molecular pathways that regulate the specification and development of the organizer, including the TGF-beta and beta-catenin signaling pathways.

We also characterized subsequent processes of gastrulation and germ layer formation in this system. Gastrulation is a critical phase of early development that lays the foundation for metazoans body plans by generating the three principal germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm and endoderm).  Morphogenetic events at the blastopore, the site of gastrulation, influence formation of the through-gut (openings of mouth and anus).  As such, gastrulation plays a pivotal role in evolutionary scenarios concerning the origins and divergence of the through-gut within metazoans. We used time-lapse microscopy to characterize this process in Crepidula, which occurs by epiboly, and to map the behavior of individual cells that contribute to the blastopore, mouth, anus and various germ layers.  We also began to characterize gene expression in these tissues in order to build gene regulatory networks that control their specification and development.

As part of this study we optimized procedures to generate transgenic embryos expressing a fluorescently tagged protein. This is the first successful demonstration of targeted gene modification in any spiralian species, which opens the doors for powerful functional studies using this model system.  

Finally, this research afforded opportunities to educate and train numerous individuals and to establish many fruitful collaborations with other national and international laboratories.
